etymologies: late 18th century: from French hoquet ‘hiccup’; in Old French the sense was ‘hitch, sudden interruption’ which also existed in Middle English

definitions: a spasmodic or interrupted effect in medieval and contemporary music, produced by dividing a melody between two parts, notes in one part coinciding with rests in the other.
shortDefinitions: spasmodic or interrupted effect in medieval and contemporary music, produced by dividing melody between two parts, notes in one part coinciding with rests in other
